reviewText:
Crown and Council is a simple time-waster.  As a free game, and an entertaining way to spend at least a few minutes, it is hard to not recommend it.

It just isn't a well-designed game.  By design, it is a simply strategy title.  You gain gold based on the territory that you hold, and spend gold to attempt to capture enemy territories.  Whether or not your attempt succeeds comes down to random chance.  Unfortunately, the game is so simple that it is ruled by that random chance.

You can neither shift the odds of battle nor mitigate risk.  You cannot build superior force short of stockpiling gold in order to launch successive separate attempts.  While the game later introduces more factors, at its core there are few strategic decisions to be made.  That minimal strategy ultimately means nothing when results are entirely random, where the difference between taking three territories in a single turn and failing to take any territory for three turns straight is entirely random chance.

Crown and Council, at its core, takes the chance-based gameplay of titles like Risk and Dice Wars and increases the random nature further.

On more technological matters, there is no ability to resize the game window.  If your vertical resolution is around 768 (such as with laptops or even smaller desktop monitors), then the Windows taskbar will cover the button used to end your turn.  You either have to move your taskbar to the side (revealing the button), or maximize the game window (revealing the top few clickable pixels of the button) to proceed.

reviewText:
So lets just get this out of the way, yes the game is free, yes its by mojang, no being a free game does not exempt it from being criticized.

The game is a clone of the old Risk games, you start your turn with a finite number of actions indicated by Gold, every action costs varying amounts of it with basic attacks only costing one and fortification upgrades costing upwards of 6 gold. Now you get more gold by capturing neighboring nations and holding them, in fact it takes a turn before they start producing gold for you.

However producing gold is all they do, they confer no bonuses to attack or defense, no price reduction in actions, there is no way to affect the outcome of an action, the game gives you fortifications you can place which supposedly increase one's defensive capabilities, but in a game powered strictly by RNG with no skill involved these fortifications mean little when they can fall in a single action and an empty node can stand the test of time and weather an entire turn worth of actions.

As I said previously, there is no strategy, there is no thought to this game (either in production or playing), the game is essientially a clicker game, just keep clicking nodes you don't own and eventually you'll win

Pros
None

Cons
*Terrible Music and repeditive sound effects quickly become irritating within minutes of starting.
*Terrible controls, yes thats right a mouse driven game with terrible controls. Clicking works whenever it chooses to and seems to be affected by the same RNG that controls the rest of the game".
*RNG

reviewText:
First of all: I see the idea and concept behind this little game, a bit of potential and maybe even a little fun factor.
I see it, that however doesn't mean any of these factors exists in the game in that particular fashion.
To be fair, this is originally a jam game and I do neither expect it to be perfect, nor finished. But I expect it to accomplish basically functioning gameplay.

PROS:
+ It has a neat soundtrack
+ It is easy to understand and to play

CONS:
- It is repetitive and gets boring very quickly
- It has pretty much no strategic content or gameplay (yet calls itself a strategy game)
--- It is COMPLETELY based on RNG and Luck. It doesn't matter if you are a damn military computer or the world record holder of the lowest IQ point quota ever scored: If RNGesus isn't with you, some levels are completely impossible.

Here, a little example:
I own 3 counties with towers, my enemy 5 without. I attack with all of my 5 gold, all attacks fail. My enemy defeats and conquers my counties in 3 attacks straight.

Another example:
The first water level (the one that introduces fleets). I actually got stuck at this level.

I manage to conquer 6 counties after 7 turns and built a tower on each of them. The other three AI's conquer all my counties first try in that very round. Game over. Try again.
And again.
And yet again.
And- you know the drill now.

If you are patient enough to try and try and try the same level over and over again to hope for a little, tiny, puny help of RNGesus, this game is perfect for you. If you aren't, welcome to the club. This game aswell fails to deliver another aspect it promises, fast pace, as the quarrels can turn out to become rather long, when (and this is no exaggeration) for 23 rounds straight, there have been !!!2!!! successful fights.

I am actually very sorry that I have to rate this game so negatively. With a bit of tweaking, adding more (or rather any) strategic aspects, a little more diversity in gameplay and especially not a pure focus on RNG, this little game might actually become a nice little timekiller. At this point however: Pure RNG-Frustration and low entertainment value.

Crown and Council is a well-balanced, fast-paced little gem. It captures what's fun about the better versions of Risk while abstracting away boring elements like card-drawing and troop shuffling.

There's a good balance between aggression, research, industry and fortification, and the AI is good enough to provide entertainment, if not a serious challenge. (It'd be far better if it gave up on research...)

Don't be put off by the first few tutorial levels. Until you get access to all your actions, the game comes across as a shallow RNG slog, but the strategy is in there -- you'll just need some options besides attack" and "fortify."

Don't worry about the low Steam rating either. A lot of players are checking this out because it's "by Mojang!" and not quite getting that it's "a free spare-time project by one of Mojang's artists!"

The screenshots communicate exactly what you're in for. If you like things like this

Lots of people are complaining about the RNG, which may or may not be fair. What bugs me personally are two things, one small and one large:

1. The smaller thing, though still quite annoying, is the interface. Clicking often doesn't work, and I'm constantly having to re-select what action I want to do.

2. The bigger thing is that there is a degenerate strategy: just attack with armies when possible, and fleets otherwise. Oh, there is a little bit of tactics when you take territories in order to discourage the AI from going a certain direction, since it prefers to attack neutral countries. And you sometimes can and should build cities and castles when you don't have the resources to attack. But the technology investment, as far as I can tell, is worthless, because if you spend money on the tech buildings (are they cathedrals? I forget), you've just given up a huge number of territories that could have been taken instead. The game's too short for tech to matter.

Needs Considerable Work\nThough the game may be free, all that entitles you to is some free frustration.  The game plays through a series of board-game style maps, each one offering further features.  The game plays a bit like Risk with some minor economic management.  However, the game is frequently a buggy mess.  It often has a hard time understanding where you are clicking, the success of an attack is either completely random or at least completely unexplained, and the game will frequently freeze up and require you to restart.  All in all, it's a poor effort, but with some bug fixes and perhaps a multiplayer I could see this becoming a fun casual time waster.

Crown and Council is a well-balanced, fast-paced little gem. It captures what's fun about the better versions of Risk while abstracting away boring elements like card-drawing and troop shuffling.

There's a good balance between aggression, research, industry and fortification, and the AI is good enough to provide entertainment, if not a serious challenge. (It'd be far better if it gave up on research...)

Don't be put off by the first few tutorial levels. Until you get access to all your actions, the game comes across as a shallow RNG slog, but the strategy is in there -- you'll just need some options besides attack" and "fortify."

Don't worry about the low Steam rating either. A lot of players are checking this out because it's "by Mojang!" and not quite getting that it's "a free spare-time project by one of Mojang's artists!"

Even though I like Mojang, I can't find this game to be recommendable for anyone. It's a simple strategy game, but you don't need anything special to win. You just attack each opponent, and win most of the time. The upgrades are almost useless, because attacking your opponent to reduce his income is the key strategy.

The game is simple and fun, as well as extremely frustrating.  There is no rhyme or reason to the damage that is done by any attack.  You simply spend coins and hope for the best.  This is perfectly okay with with the ground warfare since it generally takes 1-4 turns to take an area, but ship warfare might take 2+.  It's completely based on luck.\n\nIf you are looking to kill 10-15 minutes of your life, it's awesome for a free game.  If you want to keep all your hair and anger intact then anything more than that will ruin your day.
